title: User stuck in 2FA setup page even if group disable 2FA enforce
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When Group enforce 2FA, members of the group will be forced to setup 2FA. However, when the we remove the group 2FA enforcement. The member is still forced to setup the 2FA.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Have a group with members who do not have 2FA setup and have subgroup
1. Go to Group Settings > `General` > ` Permissions, LFS, 2FA ` > check the `Require all users in this group to setup Two-factor authentication` box and hit `Save changes`
1. Do the same for a subgroup
1. Log in as the user who doesn't have 2FA setup, see the 2FA setup screen and unable to navigate to different page
1. Go to Group settings and un check the `Require all users in this group to setup Two-factor authentication` box and `Save changes` for the top level group and then subgroup (The order is important)
1. Log in as the user who doesn't have 2FA setup again, observe that you're still stuck on the 2FA setup page

If you disable the subgroup first and then top level group, it will not trigger the bug.

### Example Project

(If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic behavior, and link to it here in the bug report)

(If you are using an older version of GitLab, this will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Disabling 2FA enforcement for groups and subgroup still force user to setup 2FA

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Users are not forced to setup 2FA after the group 2FA enforcement is disabled.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![image](/uploads/46d0ba58687b642d69a3d15e00addb15/image.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com; GitLab Enterprise Edition 13.1.0-pre 7b98ce20ee3 

### Possible Workaround

Either one of the following:

1. Remove users and add them back
1. Enable 2FA for the group and subgroups again and disable the top level group last

title: Wiki legacy routing can get in infinite redirection loop
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

This issue came out of a discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33492#note_354943870.

We redirect legacy wiki routes (`<project>/wikis`) to our new `/-/`-scoped routes (`<project>/-/wikis`).

Visiting a legacy wiki route that contains the word `wikis` twice turns into an infinite redirection.

Note, redirection of legacy wiki routes will be removed in %"14.0" (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/28848#anchor-140), so this bug will disappear with that change, if this bug is not fixed earlier.

### Steps to reproduce

- Visit `<project>/wikis/home/wikis`
- Eventually, the redirection loop will terminate at `<project>/wikis/home/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/-/wikis`.

title: [Bug] The `artifacts:expire_in` in .gitlab-ci.yml does not practically work.
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary
- Even after artifacts expire through `expire_in` in `.gitlab-ci.yml`, the size of them marked as deleted is not reflected in the `project storage`, and the download link (`https://gitlab.com/<namespace>/<project>/-/jobs/<job_number>/artifacts/download`) is still valid.

- The `artifacts:expire_in` in `.gitlab-ci.yml` does not practically seem to work.

### Steps to reproduce

| Artifacts removed | Project storage |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/c911f4bde467d160de6120114b6932d0/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/2d5a6ef44d4f94c58481925bd12c5d79/image.png) |

* This job artifacts (about 8MB) were removed automatically by `expire_in`, but `project storage` has not been reduced. 

* Also, the download link (`https://gitlab.com/<namespace>/<project>/-/jobs/<job_number>/artifacts/download`) is still valid. 

> **Note:** This job artifacts were removed 1 week ago.

* So I clicked the trash icon at the top right of the jobs trace.

| Job erased | Project storage |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/7c4b8339a2bbb0942bff7619e8dd9e73/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/aa7e15ef6226b5251f5a3c710ea19d53/image.png) |

* Only now, the size of the deleted artifacts is reflected in the `project storage`(422.3MB -> 413.5MB), and the download link (`https://gitlab.com/<namespace>/<project>/-/jobs/<job_number>/artifacts/download`) is also no longer valid.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

* Even after artifacts expire through `expire_in` in `.gitlab-ci.yml`, they are not practically removed, but are removed only when the job log is deleted by clicking the trash icon.

* The size of artifacts marked as deleted is not reflected in the `project storage`, and the download link (`https://gitlab.com/<namespace>/<project>/-/jobs/<job_number>/artifacts/download`) is still valid. 

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

* After artifacts expire through `expire_in` in `.gitlab-ci.yml`, they have to be deleted completely.

### Output of checks

* This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Related Support Tickets (internal)

1. https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/160514
1. https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/157755

title: Add PostgreSQL migration to validate the design filename text limit
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33565 Introduced a PostgreSQL limit to a `filename` of a design. 

As per our [database guide for adding limit constraints to text columns](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/strings_and_the_text_data_type.html#add-a-text-limit-constraint-to-an-existing-column) that MR did not enforce the validation of the new constraint on existing records, as this should happen at least one release after the migration runs. 

At least one milestone after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33565 is released we should add a new migration to enforce the validation.

title: Quickly resolve issues with your Cleanup policy with improved validation and notifications
description:
### Problem to solve
Administrators would like to use the GitLab Cleanup policy for tags at the Project level so that they can programmatically identify which tags should be removed or retained. To do so, they define an interval, schedule, and use [regular expression](https://xkcd.com/208/) to define a tag name to remove/retain. 

When an expiration policy has failed due to an invalid regular expression, you need to be notified, so that you can fix the issue as quickly as possible. 

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### Proposal
When a Project's Cleanup Policy has failed to run, we will notify the Project's Owner/Admin with a helpful error message via email and the UI. 

#### Email notification
> Subject: Cleanup policy has failed for project
> 
> Body:
> 
> * Project
> * Policy
> * Error
> * Link to documentation on acceptable regex

#### User experience
The UI shows the alert message and a highlighted field w/ a specific error message when they land on their Project's CI/CD settings page (where the Tag Cleanup Policy is located)

![Add_Alert_to_the_settings_page](/uploads/426cf0220743852b4b7710b89b749939/Add_Alert_to_the_settings_page.png)

![Add_Alert_on_Container_Registry_Homepage](/uploads/378b169590f2eab03a8810054111df1c/Add_Alert_on_Container_Registry_Homepage.png)

##### User experience goal
- When a policy fails to run due to a regular expression issue, the user is notified that the job failed, why, and how to fix it. 

##### UX Questions
- Who should see these errors? 
  - @icamacho I think we should only show the error to those that have the power to fix it. I believe this is Project Owner/Admin.
- What copy should we use for the email/UI?

### Further details

#### Technical considerations
The execution error happens in a worker and this process is in the background = not connected to the UI. What we could do is have the worker save the error message for the container expiration policy and when the user visits the UI the error message is displayed. 

### Permissions and Security
- There are no permissions changes required for this change

### Documentation

- https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/packages/container_registry/#expiration-policy
- https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html

### Availability & Testing

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Success looks like we see a higher success ratio of policies successfully run/failed to run and that Admin can rely on the feature to work for their project. 

#### Metrics
- We will measure this by looking at the overall adoption of the feature
- @10io is it possible to track the number of jobs that succeeded/failed?

### Links / references

title: SAST bandit container vulnerabilities
description:
At the point of this issues creation there are over 900 vulnerabilities found by klar in the docker image.

[bandit Security Dashboard](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/security/dashboard)

## Implementation plan

- [ ] Update base image to use alpine.
- [ ] Document `before_script` limitations ([link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#pre-compilation)).

## Curated list of container vulnerabilities

The Security dashboard contains a lot of duplicates. Below is the curated list of vulnerabilities, based upon a [fresh pipeline run against master](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/pipelines/160095628). There are 83 total to be addressed, most of which are of a Low severity.

 | Unapproved | Low CVE-2020-13776    | systemd      | 241-7~deb10u4         | systemd through v245 mishandles numerical usernames          |

 |            |                       |              |                       | root privileges when privileges of the 0x0 user              |

title: Project Access Tokens - Remove project membership when project access token expires
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

A project bot user (created when Project Access Token is created) is not deleted and converted to a ghost user when the access token expires. 

### Steps to reproduce

* Enable the `:resource_access_token` feature flag
  * `Feature.enable(:resource_access_token)`
* Create a Project Access Token that expires in a day. "Project" -> "Settings" -> "Access Tokens"
* Wait until the token expires
* In "Settings" -> "Members" the project bot user will still exist

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Project bot user is not deleted when access token expires

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Project bot user should be deleted and converted to a ghost user when access token expires

title: Need to figure out a workflow on how to enable Advanced Search for trial groups
description:
This issue is created to figure out a workflow on how we can enable Advanced Search for trial groups.

@joshlambert asked

Probably we need to answer a few questions,

* What is the process of enabling advanced search for trial groups?
* Should we limit the size of data to be indexed?
* Can we have an automated way to add the trial groups?
* How will we clean up the index after the trial is done?

title: Project soft delete should only occur if soft delete is enabled at group level
description:
### Problem to solve

GitLab 12.6 introduced [soft deletion of projects](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935) for Silver/Premium and higher tiers. In those tiers the "remove project" flow only schedules a project for deletion after a period of time (the default is 7 days).  Currently in those tiers it is not possible to delete projects immediately.  This has resulted in a some complaints (in order of oldest to newest):

- [Immediately remove a soft-deleted project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/191367)
- ["Is there any way to avoid this entirely in the case that confidential info has been posted on the repo?"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935#note_280903740)
- ["it was quite frustrating to have the "deleted" items persisting for 7 days"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935#note_284718369) (GitLab reporter)
- ["I discovered [delete] is not readily possible on Gitlab while the fork is pending deletion."](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935#note_284597937)
- ["I do not see an easy way of forcing the deletion before the pending date."](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935#note_291706752)
- ["This has an impact for all users of Terraform and Pulumi"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935#note_293827289)
- [Removing a fork should not take one week](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/support-forum/-/issues/5335)
- [API project DELETE backwards incompatible change](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219566)

### Proposal

1. There should be a group-level configuration option to "Enable delayed project removal", with explanation text: "Projects will be permanently deleted after a 7-day waiting period.  This period can be [customized by an admin](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/admin_area/settings/visibility_and_access_controls.html#default-deletion-adjourned-period-premium-only) in instance settings."
1. Projects should not be soft deleted on removal unless that option is enabled.
1. The project removal confirmation modal should say: ""This group has enabled a project deletion delay. Your project will be recoverable for `X` days."
1. The ["Removed projects" tab](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33502) should only appear if that option is enabled.
1. The [API documentation to remove a project](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#remove-project) should note there will be a delay if that option is enabled.
1. Projects under user namespaces to be deleted immediately

![Screen_Shot_2020-06-04_at_12.06.57_PM](/uploads/d7ddcdd101ee3e000a0b895da15757ed/Screen_Shot_2020-06-04_at_12.06.57_PM.png)

### Permissions and security

No change to existing permissions.  Only Group owners are able to change group configuration, and only Project owners are able to delete projects.

### What does success look like?

Project soft delete only occurs when the configuration option has been enabled at the group level.

Whatever approach is decided i think it should be documented and applied as a the default to the other dropdowns in the sidebar, issue, and new issue.

Update: this should also include pagination

title: Doorkeeper gem is vulnerable to a timing attack
description:
**[HackerOne report #889331](https://hackerone.com/reports/889331)** by `benaubin` on 2020-06-02, assigned to @dcouture:

### Summary

The doorkeeper gem is vulnerable to a timing attack on secret credentials (such as access tokens) similar to Rack's CVE-2019-16782 as it conducts queries using the token on an indexed database column (which makes it possible for an attacker to learn an access token in linear time).

Vulnerability number: GHSA-3hv6-4m9x-jfgj

#### Workaround

The workaround is quite simple.

Switch the secret storage strategy in Doorkeeper to hash tokens by default when storing in the database. 

I'm working on implementing a SHA512 + pepper hashing strategy (faster on 64 bit processors and more secure, using a peppered hash adds a slight additional layer of protection for little overhead), although SHA256 is currently implemented in the library. 

- `hash_token_secrets` (it's AccessToken#token value)  
- `hash_application_secrets` (it's Application#secret value)

#### Line to change:  
https://github.com/doorkeeper-gem/doorkeeper/blob/cba795448032e6f99298e71b43645b2ed4c17de4/lib/doorkeeper/models/concerns/secret_storable.rb#L94

#### Implementation of SHA512 + pepper.  
https://gist.github.com/benaubin/863b2bfb7f12c535e94c60dacfd25d07

### References

- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/18605294/is-devises-token-authenticatable-secure  
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26077553/countermeasure-to-timing-attack-against-sql-select-of-hash-token  
- http://blog.plataformatec.com.br/2013/08/devise-3-1-now-with-more-secure-defaults/  
- https://codahale.com/a-lesson-in-timing-attacks/  
- https://gist.github.com/josevalim/fb706b1e933ef01e4fb6

## Impact

Even over a network, averaging multiple requests can disclose OAuth access tokens to an attacker in linear (or, potentially, sub-linear time). Rate limiting is not a viable mitigation strategy as the attack could be performed using a botnet, and attack traffic is indistinguishable from normal traffic, at least on the first request.

title: Controller Admin::ServicesController executes more than 100 SQL queries
description:
### Description

This controller executes more than 100 SQL queries, the maximum number of queries allowed. We are introducing instance-level integration alongside service templates https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2430. Until we drop the service template functionality, we need to support the transition, this implies extra queries to disable service templates when an instance-level integration is configured.

Related to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218257 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/204804.

The number of queries should be reduced to less than 100 and the corresponding whitelisted sections of code (`Gitlab::QueryLimiting.whitelist('...')`) should be removed.

This is ~"won't do" because when we remove the service templates the number of queries will be reduced, see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220357#note_535567687.

## Roll Out Steps

title: Refactor issues analytics filter handling
description:
Issues analytics currently takes the query params, builds a path and then saves the entire path in the state. This isn't useful when we need to use specific query params in order build different endpoints. 

We need to update the filtered search component to store an object instead of a string. We'll then also need to ensure that the individual endpoints are built currently based on the filter params.

title: Show feature flag relationship in issues
description:
### Problem to solve

Broken off of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/26456#note_355378171 as a next iteration.

Our feature flag list interface is nice, but it may be unclear what a feature flag was just by reading the name. Typically this will be an operations person coming in and looking for a feature flag and wanting to understand what they are looking at.

From the issue side, we can make it clear what the status of the associated feature flag is for that feature.

The combination of these two would make it easy to understand what feature flags are for and what the status of an issue is as it relates to feature flags.

### Target audience

- Sidney, Systems Administrator, https://design.gitlab.com/research/personas#persona-sidney
- Product Manager (or others who are setting or need to know the state of feature flags)

### Further details

Future phases:
Once we connect between the feature flag and the associated issue we can further enhance the transparency by adding the environment on which the feature flag is enabled and later on the % rollout.
After that we can enable the user to click on the feature flag from the issue to change its settings and vice versa, the environment will list the associated flags within it (already exists) and a list of the related issues that can be clickable as well.

Allow users to be able to map a given feature flag to a change that introduced it. This could be linked to from various places where we show the feature flag (issue, mr, epic), adding important context.

### Proposal

We currently support linked issues from feature flags. 

In this issue we will show feature flag relationships in issues. If a feature flag has a relationship with issues, those issues will have a section for the related feature flags. 
As we broke the original issue to a smaller issues, mentions or adding feature flags in issue will not be supported.

**) Showing feature flag relationship in issues**

* ~backend [Add endpoint For fetching Feature Flags references from Issues](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52144)
* ~frontend shows the related feature flag list in an issue. This can be worked after https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/52144.
* ~documentation and ~"feature flag" rollout.


### UX Proposal

#### <strike> Associate a feature flag on issues by mentioning
 <strike> - Feature flags can be mentioned/linked in the description and comments to add relationship
<strike>  - Mentions can be made using a link to the feature flag
<strike>  - References across projects can be made with links and should be displayed with shortened links(ie gitlab-ce^89012)

#### Issues screen
  - Add a section for related feature flags
 <strike> - Feature flags can be mentioned/linked in the description and comments to add relationship
  - If there are no related feature flags, do not show the component

| Description | Mockup |
| ------ | ------ |
| Related feature flag section | ![Related_Feature_Flags](/uploads/12d97ca4fe1b1b4a54c65a48c72173dc/Related_Feature_Flags.png) |
| Issue screen | ![Issue](/uploads/116407e8b8df67d8686445389dabeef9/Issue.png) |

Additional decisions from discussions below: 
- Feature flags should follow related issues and related MRs in regards to the icon: Enabled feature flags should be displayed in green with the `feature-flag` icon. Disabled feature flags should be blue with `feature-flag-disabled` icon. Each should have a tooltip 
- Feature flag icon should have a tooltip on hover that states `Feature flag: enabled` and `Feature flag: disabled` respectively. Future iterations may include additional data such as dates. 
- Add a `question` icon in the Feature Flag section header that directs users to the documentation.

#### TODOs

* [ ] 1 for state management (loading the mentions)
* [ ] 1 for related feature flags box on the issue side

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Amount of clicks from issue to feature flag and vice vera

### Links / references

## Feature Flag for Developments

This feature is developed behind `feature_flag_contextual_issue` feature flag. The rollout issue is https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/320741.

title: Restructure Compliance Dashboard to use tabs
description:
### Problem to solve

To provide [two-person approvals](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219386) for compliance-minded organizations, we need to provide a place for approvers to approve settings changes.

### Intended users

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)

### User experience goal

This is more of a background implementation issue so the user experience goal for this instance is that the user doesn't experience any major changes other than having an ineffective tab at the top (which they will already be on).

### Solution

Restructure the Compliance dashboard to use a tabular structure instead to allow the approver to switch from `Approvals` to `Merge Requests`. For now, only `Merge Requests` will be visible as per the existing dashboard.

|Approvals|Merge Requests|
|---|---|
|![Show_full_list](/uploads/5b9ff7b5ea71bf4e93631ed7a92b373c/Show_full_list.png)|![Merge_Requests](/uploads/2f123f431e425407f905034f025af63d/Merge_Requests.png)|

### Further details

#### Implementation details

1) Using GitLab UI, we will add the [tabs with counters](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-ui/?path=/story/base-tabs-tabs--default) component to the Vue.js app on the Compliance dashboard
2) Restructure the files of the Compliance dashboard so it makes more sense in terms of a tabular structure

title: Refactor entity_path from AuditEvent details
description:
### Problem to solve

In an `AuditEvent`, the path of the affected event (`entity_path`) is stored within a JSON hash. This is difficult and slow to query and has resulted in data inconsistency within the `audit_events` table.

### Proposal 

See parent proposal: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220116

* Migration to introduce new `entity_path` column
* Route data writes to new columns. Continue populating to `details` (for a milestone) to ensure data correctness
* Update data retrieval code to read from newly created columns

### Links / references

title: Refactor target_id and target_type from AuditEvent
description:
### Problem to solve

In an `AuditEvent`, the `target_id` and `target_type` is stored within a JSON hash. This is difficult and slow to query and has resulted in data inconsistency within the `audit_events` table.

### Proposal 

See parent proposal: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220116

* Create `target_id` column
* Create `target_type` column

* Refactor write path to use new columns
* Refactor read path to handle historic data, where possible.

### Links / references

title: Refactor author_name from AuditEvent details
description:
### Problem to solve

In an `AuditEvent`, the name of the user that triggered the event `author_name` is stored within a JSON hash. This is difficult and slow to query and has resulted in data inconsistency within the `audit_events` table.

### Proposal 

See parent proposal: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220116

* Migration to introduce new `author_name` column
* Route data writes to new columns. Continue populating to `details` (for a milestone) to ensure data correctness
* Update data retrieval code to read from newly created columns

title: Public snippet cannot viewed by unauthenticated user
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Public snippet cannot viewed by unauthenticated user, by GraphQL error.

![Captura_de_Tela_2020-06-04_s_08.41.26](/uploads/cba01f26979e74d229070f42bcb1799d/Captura_de_Tela_2020-06-04_s_08.41.26.png)

![Captura_de_Tela_2020-06-04_s_08.44.28](/uploads/2f81b64bfeed0fbfa74c5181ceb2d890/Captura_de_Tela_2020-06-04_s_08.44.28.png)

### Steps to reproduce

* Create a public snippet
* Access it by anonymous page

### Example Project

https://gitlab.fretebras.com.br/snippets/173

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

This error occur after update to Community Version 13.0.3 (e2397fc2acb)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

View the public snippet snippet

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

```
vue-apollon.esm.js
message: "Cannot return null for non-nullable field Snippet.author"
```

### Output of checks

(If you are reporting a bug on GitLab.com, write: This bug happens on GitLab.com)

### Availability and Testing

Please run `package-and-qa` after frontend changes to make sure there are no unexpected regressions. We might also need new frontend specs to verify the author information is shown/not shown correctly in UI depending on pre-conditions.

title: Test entry files
description:
Currently in the security dashboard we are not testing the entry files. As we're mocking the properties (for instance the router) in the mounted components, if the entry file does not pass down these required properties the application fails even though tests are passing. 

This issue was inspired by the little accident we had in the security dashboards (which can be referenced here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217595#note_355089150).

## Implementation Plan
- [x] ~frontend write integration tests for [first_class_init.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/first_class_init.js)
- [x] ~frontend write integration tests for [security_charts_init.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/security_charts_init.js)
- [x] ~frontend write integration tests for [vulnerabilities_init_integration_spec.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vulnerabilities/vulnerabilities_init.js)

title: gemnasium-dependency_scanning job tried when the repo is no match
description:
### Summary

The `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job (Dependency Scanning) is triggered but then it fails with a `No match`, which means that there are no compatible dependency files. The scanning job is triggered even though its `rules:exists` parameter doesn't match any file of the scanned repository.

This regression was introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/31932, when fixing another regression. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/31932#note_355021318

The problem occurs because the `rules:exists`of the scanning job has many patterns. In the end the combined pattern is too complex, and the condition is skipped. This is NOT specific to Gemnasium and Dependency Scanning.
 
### Steps to reproduce

1. create a GitLab project with no file GitLab Dependency Scanning currently supports
1. include the Dependency Scanning CI template
1. create a new CI pipeline.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/openid/conformance-suite/-/jobs/580452973

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job is triggered and fails with a `No match in ...` error.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

There's no `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/31932

### Possible fixes

There's no fix but we could improve the error message. Also, we could remove the `rules:exists` param from the job definition since it's being ignored, and add a code comment to the CI config to explain this limitation.

### Implementation plan

- [x] Update analyzers and change the `No match` error to a warning, and improve the message
   - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/109
      - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/releases/v2.18.1
   - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan/-/merge_requests/79
      - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/nodejs-scan/-/releases/v2.9.6
- [x] Update the common package to change the `No match` error to a warning
   - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/122
- [ ] ~~Update the Dependency Scanning to remove the `rules:exists` from the `gemnasium-dependency_scanning` job and document the limitation. Update the spec of the Rails backend accordingly.~~
- [x] Update Dependency Scanning docs to warn about [`rules:exists` being limited to 10,000 checks](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#rulesexists), and scanning jobs possibly triggered even if there's no match
   - [x] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/43088

title: Rename whitelist to allowlist in Container Scanning
description:
## Summary

The [Container Scanning tool](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar) currently makes use of a `vulnerability whitelist` file named `clair-whitelist.yml` which is documented [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/7fc9242cf0820719a451e252b195ba0db0517075/doc/user/application_security/container_scanning/index.md#L198-206). 

Since Whitelist/Blacklist have connotations about value and map to racial terms, we should rename `clair-whitelist.yml` to `vulnerability-allowlist.yml`.

## Implementation Plan

1. [x] Change [whitelist](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/df1cdc3ba102a12f4ef96262995d28ef83fb3dff/whitelist/whitelist.go) references in the [GitLab Container Scanning tool](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar) to use the term `allowlist`
1. [x] Maintain backwards compatibility so that either a `clair-whitelist.yml` or `vulnerability-allowlist.yml` file can be provided.
1. [x] Update the [GitLab Container Scanning documentation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/7fc9242cf0820719a451e252b195ba0db0517075/doc/user/application_security/container_scanning/index.md#L198-206) to rename `Vulnerability whitelisting` to `Specifying a list of allowed vulnerabilities` and change all `whitelist` references to use `allowlist` instead.
1. [x] Update [container scanning test project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/container-scanning) to use `vulnerability-allowlist.yml`

## Involved components

- [Container Scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar)
- [Container Scanning Documentation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/7fc9242cf0820719a451e252b195ba0db0517075/doc/user/application_security/container_scanning/index.md#L198-206)
- [Container Scanning Test Project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/container-scanning)

## Testing
SET should include in any end to end test the following functionality
- Usage of `vulnerability-allowlist.yml`
- Backward compatibility to allow either `clair-whitelist.yml` or `vulnerability-allowlist.yml`

title: OOTB policy: inbound and outbound traffic
description:
### Problem to solve

Create these out-of-the-box policies:

1. Drop all outbound traffic
1. Drop all inbound traffic on any port except port 80 or 443
1. Set audit mode to enabled by default in the cluster applications project

These 2 policies are fairly simple to implement and we can implement those per application environment.

### Intended users

* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)

### User experience goal

The two out-of-the-box policies should be available to the user.

### Implementation Plan

We can add the required policies with a predefined manifest to the policy list component: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/threat_monitoring/components/network_policy_list.vue . Predefined policies will be disabled by default and upon first enable backend call will be triggered to install a policy. Once it's installed we can remove it from the list of predefined policies since it can be managed as a regular policy at this point.

Cluster applications project has to be updated to enable audit mode by default: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/cluster-applications/-/blob/master/src/default-data/cilium/values.yaml

### Documentation

### Availability & Testing

### Links / references

title: Report Pages Group by day and month
description:
### Problem to Solve

[Report Pages](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3214) encode a group by for day / week / month in a configuration file. While it is fine for a default to be set, users should be able to see the chart with different groupings without changing the chart configuration.

### Proposal

Scope:
- Make this work for Issues and MRs that Report Pages already handles today.
- Move settings into FE using a segmented control component
- Ideally this all happens on the front-end so it is fast. 
- The setting for group-by in the YAML is interpreted to be the default setting.

![Screenshot_2020-06-10_at_11.53._2x](/uploads/1039cdd0bf556ccb6f8cc96f5f7656ac/Screenshot_2020-06-10_at_11.53._2x.png)

### Notes

- One way to handle this might be to have backend always return daily values and front-end would handle the aggregation. 

- Handling it all on the front-end is not acceptance criteria if we don't think we can achieve it easily.

title: Refactor build artifact serialization
description:
# Summary

The legacy code for representing build artifacts assumes that users will only interact (download, browse, and preserve) directly with archive artifacts. This paradigm is changing: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/23847

As a result of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32811, `BuildArtifactEntity` has become out of date. Previously its `object` was a `Ci::Build`. It is now a `Ci::JobArtifact`.

This change makes this entity the wrong place to represent the `keep_path` and `browse_path` attributes, since they both act on _all_ of a build's artifacts.

## Context

The following discussion from !32811 should be addressed:

- [ ] @dosuken123 started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32811#note_352816672):  (+2 comments)

    > This path only works for `archive`-type artifact, right? Does it make sense to expose it for the other type?
    > 
    > Maybe
    > 
    > `expose :keep_path, if: -> (*) { artifact.archive? && artifact.expiring? }`
    > 
    > ? This would be more explicit.
    > 
    > In the future, we should support _keep_ action for any artifact types.

# Possible solutions

1. Remove `keep_path` and `browse_path` from `BuildArtifactEntity` so all of its attributes are only associated with the single artifact that it's representing. Create a `BuildArtifactsEntity` that has a `Ci::Build` as its `object` and represents the collection of the build's artifacts. `keep_path` and `browse_path` will become attributes on `BuildArtifactsEntity`.
2. Since updating the entities will require both frontend and backend changes, this may be a good time to migrate the features that use `BuildArtifactEntity` to [GraphQL](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/index.html#vision).

# Removal Proposal (current leading candidate)

These paths seem to be already exposed in the [BuildDetailsEntity](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/serializers/build_details_entity.rb#L34-40). Being that the action calls methods [defined on the Ci::Build class](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e8dae231bd89328255da141f0358bc00b807c9dd/app/models/ci/build.rb#L783-792) and the [path helpers](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e8dae231bd89328255da141f0358bc00b807c9dd/app/helpers/gitlab_routing_helper.rb#L178-185) accept `project` and `job` params:

```ruby
  # /*namespace_id/:project_id/-/jobs/:job_id/artifacts/keep(.:format)
  def fast_keep_project_job_artifacts_path(project, job)
    expose_fast_artifacts_path(project, job, :keep)
  end

  #  /*namespace_id/:project_id/-/jobs/:job_id/artifacts/browse(/*path)
  def fast_browse_project_job_artifacts_path(project, job)
    expose_fast_artifacts_path(project, job, :browse)
  end
```

The `BuildDetailsEntity` is a fine place for those fields to be exposed, and we can avoid introducing a new entity. Simply removing these fields from `BuildArtifactEntity` and refactoring the GitLab frontend (this is internal API only) to find the field on BuildDetails instead of on each BuildArtifact achieves what we want here.

Potential ~"follow-up": `BuildArtifactEntity` uses some performance-optimized path helpers that we might use in `BuildDetailsEntity`

title: Project delete confirmation is insufficiently scary
description:
### Problem to solve

When you delete a project, a modal is displayed asking you to confirm.  Apparently this is not clear and/or unusual enough to warn users they are doing something DESTRUCTIVE and PERMANENT, because some users still delete projects by accident :skull_crossbones: 

### Further details

One major motivation behind the ["soft delete"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/32935) feature (also referred to as ["recycle bin"](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/24866)) was that users would frequently delete projects they did not intend to.  Improving the confirmation modal is another way to discourage users from deleting projects by accident.

### Proposal

The delete confirmation modal should be scarier :scream_cat: Specifically, it should be explicit and clear about the outcome and prompt the user to take actions that reinforce the outcome.

![Soft_vs_Hard_Delete](/uploads/98f72846856d849d342189e5ccaa256a/Soft_vs_Hard_Delete.png)

### Old, insufficiently scary design

![confirmation](/uploads/d5350e325383560b1663a75263eb27f7/confirmation.png)

title: DB load balancer: Automatic retries may leak queries across transaction boundaries
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32668, we found that an idle-in-transaction timeout inside an `after_save` callback hook could cause an idle-in-transaction timeout.

PostgreSQL will sever the connection, and subsequent attempts to use the connection will trigger a `ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: PG::UnableToSend: no connection to the server`. However, https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/828c3af6822db69bf50929ae3b74a6d76868b955/ee/lib/gitlab/database/load_balancing/load_balancer.rb#L154 catches these `StatementInvalid` errors and retries them.

As @engwan showed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32668#note_351497463, the danger here is that the retry could cause SQL queries to leak across transaction boundaries. For example, I think we demonstrated that this can happen:

1. BEGIN TRANSACTION ...
1. INSERT INTO ...
1. after_save callbacks
1. idle in transaction timeout happens, PostgreSQL severs connection and ends transaction.
1. Some random SELECT or SQL call :arrow_right: `StatementInvalid` errors, EE load balancing retry runs again.
1. Rails thinks everything is okay, moves onto `after_commit` callbacks.
1. `after_commit` callbacks fail due to aborted INSERT
1. EE load balancer code retries previous step before failing

The PostgreSQL client library shows `FATAL:  terminating connection due to idle-in-transaction timeout`, but I'm not quite sure if this is error is passed to Rails clients. I see Rails has a `QueryAborted` error for MySQL, but not for PostgreSQL.

@engwan was also concerned about other cases:

>>>
But I'm also concerned about the other cases. For example, Web to DB network issues.
That would also be a StatementInvalid exception and lead to some queries being retried in a separate transaction right? 
>>>

title: Generic Metrics API MVC
description:
### Problem to solve

This issue represents the first step we will take toward storing metrics generically for the purposes of storing aggregated and computed data. The epic has more detail about what that means and why it matters.

Users should be able to write and read custom aggregated metrics from our storage. They will be read and shown by analytics widgets at [Generic Analytics Report Pages](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3214)

### Scope

The first release of our MVC is to satisfy need for storing aggregated data for use in [Generic Analytics Report Pages](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3214). We will not advertise the API for customer use until we know it works with a few scenarios and can be sure that we won't be breaking customers as we figure it out.

### Possible Places to Start

Our default option is [New Members Chart](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/217488) only because it is what we have already been talking about and working on. 

But we have other options and I am willing to change the plan for [13.2](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/manage/-/issues/16681) if we have good technical reasons to pursue an alternative. A few alternatives come to mind:

* For example: [Test Code Coverage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220206)
* Or: [Burn-up / Burn-down](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3105#note_354490513)

If we want to take an approach to solving this that doesn't define a store for new metrics (such as in [Generic Metrics API](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3105)) but instead consumes metrics that already exist in other GitLab tables, please call this out so we can spin up a separate issue for that. Ultimately do want to have a new place to persist aggregations and calculations that don't exist elsewhere, but it is optional as to whether we solve for that in this issue or a follow-on issue.

### Proposal

#### POST /api/v4/analytics/reports/series/
Create an API for storing and retrieving custom data with following params

| param | type | comment |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| **series_slug** | string | Required |
| series_value_type | enum((integer, float, ratio, set) | value type for given series. Should be used when creating new series. Optional. |
| namespace_id | integer | reference id to scope namespace. namespace_id or project_id is required to be present if creating new series. |
| project_id | integer | reference id to scope project. namespace_id or project_id is required to be present if creating new series. |
| **points** | array | array of series points to add. |

Point array members should be in form of:

| param | type | comment |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| **point_timestamp** | timestamp | Required |
| aggregation_level | enum (day, week, month, year) | Optional. Default: day |
| **value** | depends on series value type (integer, float, json) | Required |
| value_denominator | integer | additional column for ratio value type. Optional. |

* The endpoint should store all or none of points provided.
* Data points can't be overridden.
* New series with associated author should be created if a series with given name doesn't exist
* Only user who created a series can write new data to this series.
* Value validation should happen according to series definition.
* TODO: "set" value type should have max length limit.

Also create (if not created before in scope of other issues)

#### GET /api/v4/analytics/reports/series/:series_slug
with following possible params

| param | type | comment |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| **series_slug** | string | Required. Data series slug we pull from |
| from | timestamp | Filter value to get data points. Optional. |
| to | timestamp | Filter value to get data points. Optional. |
| chart_type | enum(bar,line)  | Serializer chart selection. Optional. Default to `bar` |

With response according to given chart_type.

* period between from and to shouldn't be more than 12 month.
* for now return daily data only. 
* TODO: Who should be able to read those generic metrics?

### Technical details

To store data points we need to create `analytics_data_series` and `analytics_data_points` tables with following structure:

`analytics_data_series`

| column | type | comment |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| id | bigint | required |
| series_slug | string | series slug. unique. required |
| value_type | enum(integer, float, ratio, set) |  required |
| namespace_id | integer | reference id to scope namespace|
| project_id | integer | reference id to scope project |
| owner_id | integer | reference id to user who created the series |
| created_at | timestamp | |
on of namespace_id or project_id is required.


`analytics_data_points`

| column | type | comment |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| id | bigint | data point id
| series_id | bigint | associated series id |
| point_timestamp | timestamp | |
| aggregation_level | enum | (day, week, month, year)
| value | float | simple value |
| value_denominator | integer | additional column for ratio value type |
| values_set | jsonb | column for "set" value_type e.g. {L1: count, L2: count, L3: count} | 
| created_at | timestamp | |


### Permissions and Security

TBD

title: Read Only Legacy Feature Flags
description:
Make legacy feature flags read only in the UI.

title: Locate Secure CA use of problematic terms
description:

Locate Secure CA use of "Blacklist" and "Whitelist" to "allowlist" and "blocklist" (except LC where we're doing denylist)

Locate Secure CA use of "Master" and "Slave"

these are problematic terms and should not be used

### Proposal

#### Identify & Document
Let's identify instances of problematic terms and document them (here)

NB: there is already one issue for CS: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220262


### Further details

#### Next Steps (out of the scope of this issue)

##### Quick Fix
For any that are documentation/ui only let's quickly replace/update user facing references where possible (docs, UI) and update appropriate tests if applicable

##### GitLab Backlog
For Backend references let's make backlog issues and ask for community contribution/help to update

Where referencing third parties feel free to use "blacklist (as per VENDOR terms, we prefer blocklist)" etc and make a backlog item

For Items/terms inherited from dependencies (like clair, redis) let's make a backlog item acknowledging we have requested the upstream project to change and check on it occasionally. @NicoleSchwartz will make these if you feel uncomfortable dong so.

If updates are made check the tests as you may need to update them!

title: Create "No Access" Role
description:
<!-- triage-serverless PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
The following page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.
<!-- triage-serverless PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->

### Problem to solve
In Gitlab.com, we use top-level groups as the construct that defines an organization's workspace. If an organization is using SSO, users are automatically added to the top-level group as Guest, which for some organizations is too permissive. In a self-managed instance, administrators can add users to an instance and selectively add them to groups/projects as needed. We need to simulate that experience for Gitlab.com customers. 

### Intended users

* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### User experience goal

Administrators can add members to the parent group for SSO purposes but they don't automatically have access to projects/groups underneath. This is one of the top reasons why customers want to disable inheritance (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33534). If we had this feature we could essentially ask administrators to add users to the levels they need access to instead of marking what needs to be excluded from the hierarchy. So a similar result but a different way of tackling the need.

### Proposal
Create a role that gives no access to top-level resources. The experience should be similar to not existing in the top-level group.
- The "unassigned" role should only be assignable to users in the top-level group via the UI or API. 
- A user with the "no access" role should not be able to list subgroups/projects unless they have been explicitly added to them. 
- If a user with the "unassigned" role is explicitly added to a group further down in the hierarchy, our existing inheritance model will apply to any subgroups or projects underneath. 
- A user with the "unassigned" role should not have access to any of the top-level group resources.
- If a "unassigned" role user hasn't been added to any other group/project, all they will see in their groups is the top-level group. Trying to access it will give them a limited view of the group. In the section where the group hierarchy is normally shown they will see a message "You don't have access to any resources in this group."
- Users with the "unassigned" role are shown in the members list if they are direct members.  Users with the "unassigned" role are not shown in the members list if they are inherited members. 
- This role should be available as an option in the `Default membership role` in SAML/SSO configuration.
- This role should be available in gitlab.com and self managed. Silver/Premium and above.

### Further details

A huge challenge with [disabling group inheritance](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33534) has been the sensitivity of the underlying code. It is proving very hard to change. As pointed out in @mksionek's MR, we're now considering a [working group](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/28695#note_351664742) and doing more investigation on all the potential effects.

* **MyCompany** (top-level group)
  * *SecretGroup* (subgroup)
  * **General** (subgroup)

Since SAML is currently configured at the top-level group, users will SSO in. At a minimum, they have Guest access to **MyCompany** group, so they have Guest access to all subgroups. This includes *SecretGroup*, so it's not possible to keep the projects in *SecretGroup* confidential.

Instead of allowing members to be in **MyCompany** as Guests at minimum, introduce a `No Role` membership. New members who are added to **MyCompany** via SAML or otherwise get added as `No Role`s to **MyCompany**.

Being a `No Role` means that you can do almost nothing in the group. While inheritance is technically still in place since `No Role` is being inherited into *SecretGroup* and **General**, it doesn't matter since you can't do or see anything with `No Role`.

Therefore, I need to add/update my member's specific roles in *SecretGroup* and **General**. For a new member, I can just add them to **General** as a Guest ... Owner to give them access where they can start contributing. Their `No Role` access in *SecretGroup* means that subgroup remains a secret.

### Permissions and Security

title: Add a 'regulated' setting to compliance frameworks for compliance management and reporting
description:

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Trytodefinethewho/what/whyoftheopportunityasauserstory.Forexample,"Asa(who),Iwant(what),soIcan(why/value)." -->

In %"12.10" we introduced [compliance framework labels for projects](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/118671) to help customers delineate between regulated and non-regulated projects. This is a way for customers to provide a passive notice to users in their groups and projects about a project's special requirements, but it also allows GitLab to provide specific reporting or settings inheritance for only projects with these compliance requirements.

Currently, there's no way to support organizations who wish to enforce settings using the paradigm established in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/213601, but who may not comply with specific frameworks or frameworks currently supported in GitLab.

### Intended users

[Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Cameron should be able to navigate to a group and toggle a compliance framework that identifies as `regulated`, which would then enforce settings like Merge Request approvals in Projects using that compliance framework.

title: New Audit Event: AuditEvents not being created when creating/deleting SSHKeys/GPGKeys via API
description:
### Problem to solve

Via the API, we allow users or admins to create/destroy SSH keys and GPG Keys. In the [lib/api/users.rb](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/users.rb),
this is performed directly using ActiveRecord operations like say `user.keys.new(ssh_key_params).save`.  With this approach, AuditEvents are not being created.

### Proposal

We have services (like `Keys::CreateService`) which take in the required params and do the same operation, while also making sure that AuditEvents are being created for these operations.  The API should use these services to ensure AuditEvents are created when creating/destroying GPG and SSH keys.

### Further details

A non-exhaustive list of endpoints where changes are required:

### SSH Keys

- [x] `POST :id/keys` - Fix: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/33859
- [x] `POST keys` - Fix: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34645
- [x] `DELETE :id/keys/:key_id`
   - [x] Technical debt fix for using `DestroyService` in this endpoint - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34535
   - [x] Record audit event via `EE::Keys::DestroyService` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65615
- [x] `DELETE keys/:key_id`
   - [x] Technical debt fix for using `DestroyService` in this endpoint: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34718
   - [x] Record audit event via `EE::Keys::DestroyService` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65615


### GPG Keys

- [x] `POST ':id/gpg_keys'`
   - [x] Technical debt fix for using `CreateService` in this endpoint: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34737
   - [x] Record audit event fix: Instrument `EE::GPGKeys::CreateService` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65973
- [x] `POST 'gpg_keys'`
   - [x] Technical debt fix for using `CreateService` in this endpoint: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34817
   - [x] Record audit event fix: Instrument `EE::GPGKeys::CreateService` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65973
- [x] `DELETE ':id/gpg_keys/:key_id'` 
   - [x] Technical debt fix for using `DestroyService` in this endpoint: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/34935
   - [x] Record audit event fix: Instrument `EE::GPGKeys::DestroyService` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65973
- [x] `DELETE 'gpg_keys/key_id'`
   - [x] Technical debt fix for using `DestroyService` in this endpoint: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35033
   - [x] Record audit event fix: Instrument `EE::GPGKeys::DestroyService` - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65973

The changes could be big, so it would make sense to split these changes across multiple MRs (~ 3 MRs for 3 services).

title: Repository cleanup should prune all loose objects within 30 minutes
description:
## Problem to solve

Using repository cleanup (https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/repository/reducing_the_repo_size_using_git.html#using-the-bfg-repo-cleaner) triggers housekeeping, but `git gc` doesn't prune all loose Git objects. This means they can still be accessed through the web interface if the object id is known, and the repo size isn't reduced immediately.

## Further details

## Proposal

~~When triggering house keeping use `git gc --prune=30.minutes.ago`~~

~~https://git-scm.com/docs/git-gc#Documentation/git-gc.txt---pruneltdategt~~

The original proposal can cause some data corruption and therefore not feasible (see [this thread](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220104#note_396967869) for details).

To avoid race conditions in Git and possible corruption:

1. Move unreferenced objects into a different packfile
1. Exclude them from the size calculation done by `du -sk`
1. Communicate to the user 1) which objects have been isolated and are set to be deleted in `X` days

title: [Wiki] Activity not created for nested pages
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

### Summary

During verification tests, it has been discovered that not all wiki pages get events added for them following git pushes. If pages that have been pushed are in sub-directories (such as https://gitlab.com/alexkalderimis/kitty.conf/-/wikis/nested/page_be or https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/create-stage/-/wikis/logs/decision_be or https://gitlab.com/alexkalderimis/kitty.conf/-/wikis/nested/foo) then no activity is recorded.


### Steps to reproduce

- Clone a wiki repository
- Create a file named 'some-file.md'
- Create a file named 'some-directory/some-file.md'
- Add some content
- Commit and push

Note that no event is added for the page in the subdirectory.

### Example Project

This is visible in https://gitlab.com/alexkalderimis/kitty.conf

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

No events are created

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Events are created

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Consolidation and Categorization of Audit Event Types
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

Audit events is a tool for owners and administrators to track user or system driven changes.

We currently allow events to be [filtered](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/audit_events.html) by `dates`, `entity_type` and `entity_id`.

While this is helpful, there is no easy way for administrators **to retrieve targeted audit events** such as: `In the past one month how many users were added to Project A`? Let's take another example of a data breach: a particular user account was compromised, it is currently not possible to fetch login events on the user in the past 24 hours: `Fetch all login attempts for User X in the last 24 hours`.

The data that can help retrieve specific results is currently stored in free form text in the database, such as: `Changed number of required approvals from 0 to 1`, `Repository Download Started`, `Removed user access via system job. Reason: access expired on 2020-01-24`.

In order to make the audit logs more meaningful and retrievable, it leads to the need to categorize or label audit event types based on the action that is being performed.

### Proposal

<details>
<summary>List of action types</summary>

| action_type                                    |
|------------------------------------------------|
| create_deploy_key                              |
| add_email                                      |
| add_group                                      |
| add_project                                    |
| add_project_access                             |
| add_protected_branch                           |
| add_protected_branch                           |
| add_ssh_key                                    |
| add_user_access                                |
| archive_project                                |
| change_prevent_merge_request_approval_reviewers |
| change_access_level                            |
| change_builds_access_level                     |
| change_forking_access_level                    |
| change_issues_access_level                     |
| change_merge_request_approval_from_author      |
| change_merge_requests_access_level             |
| change_metrics_dashboard_access_level          |
| change_number_of_required_approvals            |
| change_pages_access_level                      |
| change_password                                |
| change_project_name                            |
| change_project_namespace                       |
| change_project_path                            |
| change_project_visibility                      |
| change_release                                 |
| change_release_milestone                       |
| change_repository_access_level                 |
| change_snippets_access_level                   |
| change_username                                |
| change_wiki_access_level                       |
| create_release                                 |
| create_release_ios_daily_build                 |
| create_release_job                             |
| grant_oauth_access                             |
| login                                          |
| login_failed                                   |
| login_with_bitbucket                           |
| login_with_github                              |
| login_with_github_failed                       |
| login_with_google_oauth2                       |
| login_with_google_oauth2_failed                |
| login_with_group_saml                          |
| login_with_salesforce                          |
| login_with_two_factor                          |
| login_with_two_factor_via_u2f_device           |
| mark_group_for_deletion                        |
| mark_project_for_deletion                      |
| remove_email                                   |
| remove_project                                 |
| remove_protected_branch                        |
| remove_user_access                             |
| request_password_reset                         |
| start_repository_download                      |
| start_export_file_download                     |

</details>

We can break the efforts into the following 4 stages:
 
**Stage 1:** Capture `action_type`

- Create a column `action_type` in `audit_events`. We have an option to store known `action_type` as an enum or in a reference table. To facilitate easier addition, let's start with an enum. 
- Ensure appropriate index is created for `action_type`. We will enable search on this field.

**Stage 2:** Save `action_type` for new audit events

- Modify all _write_ services to write to the new column (i.e. `AuditEventService` and `Auditor`)
- Add a new field to the development [doc](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/audit_event_guide/) 

**Stage 3:** Categorise existing audit events

- Examine existing audit events and start categorizing them
- Perform data migration to populate `action_type` in batches. May require input from specific teams

Note: Stage 2 and 3 can be executed in parallel.

**Stage 4:** Expose filter by `action_type` in Audit event dashboard and  API

Once we have bucketed data, we can allow administrators to filter audit events based on the `action_type`.

<details>

<summary>Old proposal</summary>

### Proposal

To start with, we can label audit events into action types.

There are certain action types that are common to most entities, such as:

| Common action types  |
|---------|
| Create  |
| Update  |
| Delete  |
| Restore |

While, we can also have specific action targeted to entities such as:

| Source  | Target | Action Type                        |
| ------  | ------ | ------                             |
| Project | User   | Export request                     |
| Project | System | Export complete                    |
| Project | User   | Grant access level Maintainer      |
| User    | User   | New password request               |

This raises the question: do we want to filter action based on entities? It could potentially change how we store possible values for `action_types`, but can be addressed later with non-breakable changes.

## Implementation plan

We can break the efforts into the following 4 stages:
 
**Stage 1:** Capture `action_type`

- Create a column `action_type` in `audit_events`. This can be an enum field, as we want to know the possible values this column can hold. We also want to avoid free form text to make the field easily queryable
- **To decide:** The `action_type` list can be large and will be evolving - do we want to store possible values in a yaml file?

**Stage 2:** Categorize existing audit events

- Examine existing audit events and start categorizing them
- Perform data migration to populate action types in stages (for e.g. `login`, `project events`,.. can be done separate migrations). May require input from specific teams

**Stage 3:** Save `action_type` for new audit events

As part of [audit event service refactoring](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5899) efforts, we can make changes to the service to accept a parameter for `action_type`.

Note: Stage 2 and 3 can be executed in parallel.

**Stage 4:** Expose filter by `action_type` in Audit event dashboard and API

Once we have bucketed data, we can allow administrators to filter audit events based on the action type.

This will also allow us to create template reports such as `Authentication and Authorization`, `Access Level`, and so on. It can also be enhanced to build features that will let customers create their own report based on the actions. And, it can be set to generate at regular intervals such as `Generate and email Access level report once a week`.

</details>

## Future work

In certain instances, `entity` (source) and `target` may be different: `User A was added as a maintainer to Project B`. Here, the `entity` is `Project B` and source is `User A`. Administrators should be able to query by `source` or `target` or combination of both.

## References / Links

Refer to @djensen's [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216845#note_346928009) for wider context.

title: Write a script to associate MR creators by username after a BitBucket Server import
description:
## Current state

A customer imported a project from [Bitbucket Server](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/import/bitbucket_server.html) to GitLab (self-hosted). Due to network/compliance restrictions, they weren't able to have a direct connection to the original Bitbucket Server. To work around that, they created a proxy Bitbucket Server (clone of the original) that has a connection to the GitLab server and imported a tarball export from the original BitBucket server. However, the tarball export did not include emails. When import was run from the proxy to GitLab, the original MR creators were not assigned (as the assignment is done by matching emails) and the importer user was [assigned](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/import/bitbucket_server.html#user-assignment) as the MR creator for all MRs. Additionally, a note was [added](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/import/bitbucket_server.html#user-assignment) to the description of each one of the MRs specifying the original creator by the handle. 

E.g. "Created by: username":
![image](/uploads/efc07ba9b92ca2b7106afef58b6e5451/image.png)

The customer is now using the imported project but desires that the MR assignments are reestablished.

## Desired solution

Create a script that the customer can run one time on the GitLab server after the import to reassociate the MR creator assignments. This script would use the fact that the usernames listed as creators in the description filed are the same as their email address usernames (the part before the `@` sign).

## Links
* [BitBucket Server Importer documantation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/import/bitbucket_server.html)
* [Issue requesting that BitBucker Server matches users by username, in addition to emails](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/218609)

title: Increase the value size limit for instance level variables
description:
We have a database limit size of [1024 characters](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/b378d28e473ff26c6205ad79d58a4f983aa0fa7b/db/structure.sql#L1166) for the encrypted values of instance level CI/CD variables, which yields around 700 usable characters. But this size is not enough to store certificates with raw lengths of about 8000 characters.

## Proposal 

Bump the limit to `13000` characters, this should be enough to hold values of around 10000 characters.

title: Tracking Primary key integer overflow risk for `events.id`
description:
`events` is a large table with a lot of records. It's primary key is an integer-typed sequence which results in a maximum number of 2,147,483,647 records with a positive primary key in this table.

The current maximum id is 1.2B - or about 56.07% of the overall available space:

```
# select current_date, max(id) as current_max, ((max(id) / 2147483647.0) * 100)::integer as percentage_used from events;
 current_date | current_max | percentage_used 
--------------+-------------+-----------------
 2020-06-02   |   776354599 |           36.??
 2020-08-18   |   869560376 |           40.??
 2020-09-16   |   907979515 |           42.??
 2020-11-02   |   972089327 |           45.??
 2020-11-11   |   985382131 |           46.??
 2020-11-24   |  1003520786 |           47.??
 2021-03-19   |  1167273732 |           54.36
 2021-04-10   |  1204055209 |           56.07
```

This issue is to track the state of this, provide estimates when the overflow is expected to happen and to discuss possible solutions to it.

According to our [forecast on 2021-02-22](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/320898#note_514276636) the `events` Primary Key value is to overflow between December 2021 (at a worst case scenario using an exponential forecast) and July 2022 (following a polynomial model).

![image](/uploads/26eddf5d854f3d2e4acfa662deb75857/image.png)

epic.title: Address the Primary Key Overflow risk for the events table

title: Snippet repository import fail with older export files
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/39201 we implemented the logic to export and import snippet with repositories. In the export logic, when the project snippets have repositories we create a `snippets` folder with all the repository bundles. If none of the snippets had a repository we still created that directory.

Nevertheless, in the import logic, we had the following clause at the beginning of the class that creates the snippet repository and commit the files: `return true unless Dir.exist?(snippets_repo_bundle_path)`. This means that if the `snippets` folder is not found, we don't need to perform the snippet repository creation.

But there is a bug in this logic. For users using old (but valid) export files without the `snippets` directory, we won't create the snippet repository, leaving them without the possibility to use Git on them.

We can fix this by just removing the clause, allowing old exports, and generating all the snippets repository data.

    > One thing I did notice when testing this with ridiculous values was that the copy could be adjusted when the instance is already using more users then were licensed:
    > 
    > ![overage](https://stuff.vanlanduyt.co/file/dropstuff/Screenshot-2020-06-01-at-22.33.05-VrMKkIqVOKDfZESsjXNOrDru5Sr4Ua.png)
    > 
    > But that could go into a follow up, IMO.

title: Geo - Secondary tries to remove a file indefinitely when sync object storage is enabled but object storage is disabled for data type
description:
### Summary

The same bug described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/219960 happens when we try to remove the file store on Object Storage using the `Geo::FileRegistryRemovalWorker` when syncing object storage is enabled, but the object storage is disabled for data type on the secondary node.
