title: Geo - Secondary tries to download a file indefinitely when sync object storage is enabled but object storage is disabled for data type
description:
### Summary

Geo secondary nodes try to download a file indefinitely when syncing object storage is enabled, but the object storage is disabled for data type on the secondary node. The same bug happens when we try to remove the file using the `Geo::FileRegistryRemovalWorker`.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Enable Object Storage for LFS Objects **only** on the primary node
1. Enable `Allow this secondary node to replicate content on Object Storage` for the secondary node
1. Push a new LFS file to a repository on the primary node
1. Visit the `Admin Area` -> `Monitoring` -> `Background Jobs` -> `Retries`

    ![Screenshot_2020-06-01_17.57.15](/uploads/7800d7dda3642afb6602d7b6ec5f1531/Screenshot_2020-06-01_17.57.15.png)

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The Geo secondary node should skip the transfer when it is not allowed to replicate content on Object Storage or is not configured to store the data type on Object Storage.

title: Instrument last Git write operation per user
description:
## Problem to solve

Repository write operations are the smallest unit of measure for user activity in the Create stage. To track AMAU (Action Monthly Active Users) for the Create stage, we want to know how many users are performing repository write operations.

## Further details

Tracking the number of commits pushed is a harder metric to track than the timestamp of the last write operation. This is because some write operations might rewrite history, others might create a new branch but not actually add a commit. All of these are write operations, which means they trigger the internal API to verify if the user has write permissions to the repo/branch. This gives us enough data to work out how many users are doing write activities on repositories.

## Proposal

When Gitaly receives a write operation, Gitaly calls the internal API to check if writes are permitted by that user.

We can use this API call to track when the last write operation occurred.

The usage ping should contain a count of the number of users who performed a repository write operation in the last month.

title: License Scanning:  Failing to detect licenses using implicit `-mod=vendor` with a `vendor` directory stored in git
description:
### Summary

The `license_scanning` job was working before, but in a recent commit, the golang version was bumped to 1.14. This version of golang implicitly adds the `-mod=vendor` flag to all golang commands. However, there is a known issue that `go list all` does not work correctly when vendoring dependencies:

See:

* https://github.com/golang/go/issues/37629#issuecomment-594846140
* https://github.com/golang/go/issues/33848#issuecomment-537222782

> **Dependency analysis** Because the approach proposed here does not retain go.mod files for modules that do not contribute packages to the build (including older-than-selected versions of packages that do contribute packages), the vendor directory will not support analysis of the module graph (go list -m all, go mod why -m, and go mod graph).

### Steps to reproduce

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/merge_requests/160

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/heila/golang-license-bug

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

```bash
 ERROR -- : go list -m: can't compute 'all' using the vendor directory
 	(Use -mod=mod or -mod=readonly to bypass.)
```

https://gitlab.com/heila/golang-license-bug/-/jobs/572765258

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

```bash
go: downloading github.com/sirupsen/logrus v1.6.0
 go: downloading golang.org/x/sys v0.0.0-20190422165155-953cdadca894
 go: downloading github.com/konsorten/go-windows-terminal-sequences v1.0.3
 go: downloading github.com/stretchr/testify v1.2.2
 go: downloading github.com/pmezard/go-difflib v1.0.0
 go: downloading github.com/davecgh/go-spew v1.1.1
 # github.com/konsorten/go-windows-terminal-sequences v1.0.3
 github.com/konsorten/go-windows-terminal-sequences
 # github.com/sirupsen/logrus v1.6.0
 ## explicit
 github.com/sirupsen/logrus
 # golang.org/x/sys v0.0.0-20190422165155-953cdadca894
 golang.org/x/sys/unix
```
https://gitlab.com/xlgmokha/golang-license-bug/-/jobs/575990284

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/merge_requests/160
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/merge_requests/161

title: Deprecate and remove Pseudonymizer
description:
### Problem to solve

The Meltano team added the [Pseudonymizer feature](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/pseudonymizer.html) in 2018.  As far as I can tell, no one really uses it, and it causes some production-level issues with large databases that I raised a while ago.

### Proposal

- [x] [Deprecate](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/deprecation_guidelines/#when-can-a-feature-be-deprecated) Pseudonymizer. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77249 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77582
- [x] Remove Pseudonymizer in %15.0 (in a major release because it could be considered a breaking change).

### Related links

- [3 MRs that introduced Pseudonymizer](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/merge_requests?scope=all&state=merged&author_username=mbergeron&search=Pseudonymizer)

Thoughts @mbergeron @DouweM @deuley?

title: Improve styling of design pins
description:
<!--Thefirstfoursections:"Problemtosolve","Intendedusers", "User experience goal",and"Proposal",arestronglyrecommended,whiletherestofthesectionscanbefilledoutduring the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution.-->

### Problem to solve

The design pins are small which makes them harder to see and click. Also the white border is too thin to help the pin stand out on the design. And because blue is a common UI color, the chances of it conflicting with designs is higher.

### Proposal

[JSFiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/hduzaerL/)

* Increase the design pin size to 32 x 32 pixels. 
* Increase the border thickness to 2 pixels.
* Pin text: 16px, Bold, White.
* Add a `box-shadow` to all pins (see below).
* Change the pin background color to `#9475DB` Purple-400 from Pajamas.
* On hover, the pin will increase in size (see below).
* Disabled pins will still be gray, but will retain all other new stylings.

Pins will have a hover transition for the size increase:
```
 transform: scale3d(1, 1, 1);
 will-change: transform;
 transition: transform 350ms cubic-bezier(0, 1, 1, 1);
```

Box-shadow:
```
box-shadow: 0px 2px 4px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.32);
```

### Further details

* Zeplin defaults to yellow bg at 26x26px with a white border of 2px
* InVision pins are pink at 40x40px with no size increase on hover

title: [ENG] MVC Add contact sales option in app
description:
## Experiment summary
Currently, free users that may be interested in upgrading only have the option to upgrade on their own touchlessly via "buy now" CTAs. We know some customers prefer to talk with sales prior to upgrading and currently we do not provide them with this option in-app leaving them to either upgrade touchlessly, find our contact sales page on about.gitlab.com or to not upgrade at all. 
  
## Hypothesis
By providing good fit users with an additional resource (talk to sales option) at potential upgrade moments we will increase IACV.


Full description for this experiment can be found [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3467).
 
# Implementation information
 
MVC implementation: 
 
* The three Contact sales links in the experiment link to the following locations:
  * Bronze: https://about.gitlab.com/sales/index.html?test=inappcontactsalesbronze
  * Silver: https://about.gitlab.com/sales/index.html?test=inappcontactsalessilver
  * Gold: https://about.gitlab.com/sales/index.html?test=inappcontactsalesgold
* The link should open in the same tab
 
![image](/uploads/e73ba2fb3d019ded07e8e6f6479d1a01/image.png)
 
Full design specs can be found below. Note, in this MVC test we will be linking the user to the about.GitLab.com contact sales form with parameter tracking. The full designs contain further details for future interactive tests (in separate upcoming issues) where we can test the form hosted within GitLab, these portions of the design should be ignored for the MVC test.
* [Design specs](https://www.figma.com/file/U8VKsANgtBiqMon04VCvce/contact-sales-inApp?node-id=0%3A1)
 
# Tracking requirements 
  
* A database event on the backend that captures if a user is in the control or experiment group for this experiment that also captures user)id
* An event for users that view the experiment or control in-app pricing page
* Number of users in the control or experiment that click upgrade
* Number of users in the experiment that click any of the three contact sales links
 
* For tracking actions post submission i.e. closed-won rate, IACV etc, I've open a separate [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/marketing/marketing-operations/-/issues/3361) for Marketing to assist us with creating the needed reports

title: Productivity Analytics: Trendline chart not loading because 'status' undefined
description:

title: Change primary button for editing on files
description:
## Problem to Solve

The Web IDE is a more complete editing experience that helps to facilitate workflows across multiple files and merge requests. However, users favor the single file editing experience.

## Additional Details

This is a test that should be setup behind a feature flag to see what kind/if any feedback is generated by making this change.

## Proposal

The primary and inverted buttons of `Edit` and `Web IDE` should be switched so that Web IDE more clearly looks like a primary action that users should perform.

![Screenshot_2020-06-01_12.42.05](/uploads/31537a7d4f9bca62e7e9ff2c7bafc4ef/Screenshot_2020-06-01_12.42.05.png)

### Feature Flag

The `web_ide_primary_edit` feature flag has been enabled for `gitlab-org` and `gitlab-com` groups. It can be turned off by running the following chatops commands in slack:

```
/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org web_ide_primary_edit false
/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-com web_ide_primary_edit false
```

<details>
<summary>Original feature flag requirements</summary>

This feature needs to be done with a feature flag and it would be good to have the ability to either assign groups to the feature or assign individual users depending on what we want to do for testing.

We **SHOULD NOT** enable this by default in the %13.2 release, but rather at a minimum toggle the feature flag on for `gitlab-org` and `gitlab-com`.

</details>

[Feature flag implementation documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/)

#### Feature Flag implemenation

!35957 Introduces `web_ide_primary_edit` feature flag that can be anabled for a group.

### Instrumentation

It would be good as part of this to add telemetry to these buttons to see how many clicks each button receives: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/telemetry/snowplow.html#implementing-snowplow-js-frontend-tracking

There is also a basic A/B test process documented here: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/experiment_guide/#how-to-create-an-ab-test

#### Tracking implementation

Clicking the edit buttons will trigger the following events.

|  | event | label  | property |
| ------ | ------ | --- | --- |
| ![Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.09.59_PM](/uploads/84d8a0d045617281eeaaa60dd8cbd676/Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.09.59_PM.png) | `click_edit` | `Edit` | |
| ![Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.11.14_PM](/uploads/bbac329ceca6da11c39f7707bb975921/Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.11.14_PM.png) | `click_edit` | `Edit` | `secondary` |
| ![Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.11.19_PM](/uploads/ff23cbccbb002e6f9127cb3ddcbd4f36/Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.11.19_PM.png) | `click_edit_ide` | `Web IDE` | |
| ![Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.10.13_PM](/uploads/ed647b6f0720bce60b1494908cbc735a/Screenshot_2020-07-08_at_3.10.13_PM.png) | `click_edit_ide` | `Web IDE` | `secondary` |

title: Container Registry cleanup policy policy doesn't remove images
description:
### Summary On our self hosted gitlab instance, we have enabled the container registry tag expiration policy for several of our projects, however it does not appear to be cleaning up the registries. Gitlab does not remove any images that should meet the criteria to be removed ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? title: Replace <gl-deprecated-button> with <gl-button> in ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/project_vulnerabilities.vue
description:
**Note** - This button is more of a loading state than a clickable button. You will need to add more vulnerabilities to the project in order to see this button. For a real world example, if you scroll all the way to the bottom of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/security/dashboard/?state=DETECTED&state=CONFIRMED, you will see this button, it reads `Load more vulnerabilities`. 

## Instructions

- [ ] Using the [migration script](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/frontend/playground/create-migrate-deprecated-component-issues/-/blob/master/README.md#running-the-migration-script), or by manually editing
 the files:
  - [ ] Replace each instance of `<gl-deprecated-button>`  with `<gl-button>`.
  - [ ] Convert each variant attribute to the new variant/category combination
using the variant mapping guide.
- [ ] Take before/after screenshots of each button in the file, and upload them
in the Merge Request description.
- [ ] Request review from a designer within your stage group. If you are outside of a stage group, ping a [UX foundations member](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/product-categories/#ecosystem-group).

### Variant mapping guide

- `variant="primary"`          -> `variant="info" category="primary"`
- `variant="secondary"`        -> remove attribute
- `variant="dark"`             -> remove attribute
- `variant="light"`            -> remove attribute
- `variant="link"`             -> keep attribute
- `variant="success"`          -> `variant="success" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-success"`  -> `variant="success" category="secondary"`
- `variant="info"`             -> `variant="info" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-info"`     -> `variant="info" category="secondary"`
- `variant="warning"`          -> `variant="warning" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-warning"`  -> `variant="warning" category="secondary"`
- `variant="danger"`           -> `variant="danger" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-danger"`   -> `variant="danger" category="secondary"`

### Examples

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="outline-success" />
+ <gl-button variant="success" category="secondary" />
```

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="primary" />
+ <gl-button />
```

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="secondary" />
+ <gl-button />
```

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="success" />
+ <gl-button variant="success" category="primary" />
```

epic.title: Buttons > Vue > Migrate GlDeprecatedButton instances to GlButton in GitLab

title: Replace <gl-deprecated-button> with <gl-button> in ee/app/assets/javascripts/feature_flags/components/form.vue
description:
**Note** - This is the `Add strategy` button when creating a new feature flag:

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-29_at_12.18.22_PM](/uploads/422d79b0806c8362e0ea0730a2703a25/Screen_Shot_2020-07-29_at_12.18.22_PM.png)

You'll also need to update the spec file associated with this, it contains a `GlDeprecatedButton`. Here is the directory: `ee/spec/frontend/feature_flags/components/form_spec.js`. 

## Instructions

- [x] Using the [migration script](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/frontend/playground/create-migrate-deprecated-component-issues/-/blob/master/README.md#running-the-migration-script), or by manually editing
 the files:
  - [x] Replace each instance of `<gl-deprecated-button>`  with `<gl-button>`.
  - [x] Convert each variant attribute to the new variant/category combination
using the variant mapping guide.
- [x] Take before/after screenshots of each button in the file, and upload them
in the Merge Request description.
- [ ] Request review from a designer within your stage group. If you are outside of a stage group, ping a [UX foundations member](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/product-categories/#ecosystem-group).

### Variant mapping guide

- `variant="primary"`          -> `variant="info" category="primary"`
- `variant="secondary"`        -> remove attribute
- `variant="dark"`             -> remove attribute
- `variant="light"`            -> remove attribute
- `variant="link"`             -> keep attribute
- `variant="success"`          -> `variant="success" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-success"`  -> `variant="success" category="secondary"`
- `variant="info"`             -> `variant="info" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-info"`     -> `variant="info" category="secondary"`
- `variant="warning"`          -> `variant="warning" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-warning"`  -> `variant="warning" category="secondary"`
- `variant="danger"`           -> `variant="danger" category="primary"`
- `variant="outline-danger"`   -> `variant="danger" category="secondary"`

### Examples

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="outline-success" />
+ <gl-button variant="success" category="secondary" />
```

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="primary" />
+ <gl-button />
```

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="secondary" />
+ <gl-button />
```

```patch
- <gl-deprecated-button variant="success" />
+ <gl-button variant="success" category="primary" />
```
